comments.commentBody: Jameis Winston. Just sayin'.

Strawman... you can still send a Black Knight jock.

Sometimes you don't want a Cardale Jones. Sometimes you need an Ohioan like William Tecumseh Sherman to make em howl.

The teams in the Ivies and the service academies require in general an actual intellectual rigor and studiousness. The quote would be equally applicable today. West Point, Annapolis, Yale or Harvard are to the teams in this article as ... well as West Point, etc. are to the schools in this article.

Character once counted in college sports. As General George Marshall (VMI '01) famously said: "I want an officer for a secret and dangerous mission. Send me a West Point Football player."

I can't imagine anyone trusting a Cardale Jones, Johnny Manziel, Jameis Wilson, or others of their ilk with anything significant.

I went to a liberal arts college with an undistinguished Division III football program. I could not persuade the college President or Board that it made no sense to admit some of the best students in the world and then let them smash their heads together.  Good luck trying to get Notre Dame to give up football.

One matter that I find particularly dismaying is the continual lenghtening of football seasons, both professional and college. I'm 79. When I was in high school and college, the season for large universities was nine games, with a tenth if their season was successful. Now colleges play as many as 15 games.

The NFL now plays four exhibition and 16 regular season games. The winners then go into playoffs that can add several games.

Where will it all end? With players with their heads full of mush, unable to perform any useful work. Do the coaches, owners, university presidents care. I's sure some do but there's no stopping the steamroller.

I graduated from Notre Dame in 1975. I was studious, and skeptical of ND football at first. But by my senior year, and ND's national championships during my years there, I got hooked. And for many years, I participated in the alumni lottery for football tickets.
Unfortunately, new news about the effect of football head injuries and concussions on long term brain function is very troubling. I am afraid we need to think of football now as obsolete and unhealthy -- we need to get away from football in the 21st century in the same way we learned about, and got away from as a society, the lethal effects of tobacco in the 20th century.
Notre Dame is conducting major research, with General Electric, on technology to track head injuries in football. The trouble is, once the technology captures the event, the injury has already happened.
Rather than technology research on the effects of injury after the injury takes place, Notre Dame should make an even bolder move and quit playing football altogether. This, as they say, probably "is never going to happen." especially seeing Notre Dame's new plans to actually integrate new academic facilities with the walls of an expanded stadium.
Five hundred years from now, will Notre Dame look like the ruins of a Colosseum, or the hallowed halls of learning of an Oxford or Cambridge?
The choice for that fork in the road is, unfortunately, now. It is a Profiles in Courage moment for Notre Dame leadership.

Why not let the football players major in football? They could then learn about topics related to something that actually interests them, and maybe learn something along the way.  Theatre students perform in school productions, right?
An English scholar among his peers.  Have you ever seen an FSU press conference?  It could go directly to SNL; no changes needed.

Nice amalgamation.

Harbaugh didn't understand the question. Of course he knows what dismay means.

He simply was coachspeaking his way out of answering the question, much to our dismay.

But of course I'm sure you already understood that.
Honestly, I know what "dismayed" means, but if someone asked me if I found an experience dismaying, I wouldn't understand the question.

Catching a piece of Harbaugh's introductory press conference today, I was amused by his answer when asked if his recent NFL experience had been dismaying.
After he gave a generic response that did not answer the question, the reporter again asked if he had found the experience "dismaying."
A puzzled look came across Harbaugh's face and he finally admitted, "I don't know the meaning of that...I'm sorry, I just don't know what that means."
So a man making millions to coach football at one of the nation's elite public universities, and a man who already has successfully coached at Stanford, does not know the meaning of the word dismayed.
Then it dawned on me that the nation's sports pages could now proclaim truly Harbaugh's positive attitude by saying he "doesn't know the meaning of the word dismayed."
What a farce are big-time college sports.

Frank L:

The back-turning was petulant and unprofessional,

***
I read on Bloomberg's website that many of the cops at the funerals were from out of town. It wasn't necessarily NYPD officers who turned their backs.
aren't they already doing that+?

Higher education lacks ambition.

Why not have student-seamstresses sew the team uniforms while student-brewers manufacture the game beverages sold by student-servers in a stadium maintained by student-caretakers?

You are thinking that it’s all about Geopolitics, as if the Palestinians are the only people subject to world situations.
I hear nothing about culture/Religion; Nothing from ‘within’ people, only REACTION to circumstances.
The HAMAS charter is an example of how wrong you are. Some of it are quotes from the Quran.
NOTHING that Israel does (or will do) matters. Israel must ‘disappear’. The Jews must die. Oh wait, I’m wrong. The command is not for the Jews to die… it’s for the Muslim to KILL the Jews.
Do you understand the difference?
And then this: “The people with agency, with options, are not using them, just waiting for the inevitable, thinking status quo will go on forever.”
Where did you get this idea? Israelis think that the status quo will go forever?

There is no solution to this conflict. Not a peaceful one.

Nonsense! The people of Gaza have options. They cannot repudiate the root cause of their misery; repudiate Hamas, repudiate hatred and violence, repudiate the commitment to destroy Israel and "kill all the Jews."

They can chose life. They can choice peace instead of rockets and murdering of Israeli school children. They can accept the State of Israel and negotiate and peaceful and economically productive relationship with Israel to benefit all in the area.
As Golda Meir once said:  When the palestinians love their children more than they hate Israel, there will be peace.

"The alternative is war without end."

No, that is the Israeli view, but it is not true. War without end is not an option. The status quo is not an option.

Either change something fundamental, or the fundamentals will change anyway out of control of those who could have changed them a different way.

It would be unpredictable what would happen, it may take longer or shorter, but something will give.

Many pressures are building. Every single one of them is hostile to Israel. All are controllable today, but each is growing. Status quo offers nothing but a variety of walls for Israel to hit.

Those who lead in the direction of those walls are leading Israel into disaster, even as they pound their chests and proclaim other things.

The Palestinians will suffer too, but they have nowhere to go and no options, so that is just how it is. The people with agency, with options, are not using them, just waiting for the inevitable, thinking status quo will go on forever.

The more enlightening message here is prevention.  How do we make our environment and behavioral choices easier so that people feel natural to eat right and exercise properly.  The emphasis of this article is much on the end treatments, e.g. to keep people on dialysis.  But really money, insurance, incentives should be preventing people from getting there in the first place.  Is there money to be made in preventive measures?  Can Apple and Google work with communities to redefine the true meaning of health.   And getting there is not always the result of taking insulin and anti hypertensives.  It is rethinking health, from expensive end user treatments to sensible and healthy society.  This can be done, but it will take a sensible and influential entity to step in and steer into that direction.

How about acknowledging that Mr. Elson was too irresponsible to take care of himself?  That $350 a month he refused to pay, and his refusal to comply with his medication regimen, has now cost him a lot more than money. Obamacare isn't the problem here. People's refusal to take responsibilty for their lives, in the name of "I don't need no stinkin' gummint healthcare, I'd rather have cable tv, and not take my medication," is. Yes, that's callous, but that's what it boils down to.

Yeah, no Popes in the lot. I feel sorry for Harbaugh, who got a raw deal this year and I hope he's happy at Michigan.

Today was 14 straight hours of cooking. Tomorrow's the busy day, so I probably won't be checking in. Have a good Eve, all.

We've had enough of Democratic leaders who "don't like fighting."

We've had enough of Democratic leaders who appeal to the better nature of money power. They don't have a better nature.

We've had enough of Democrats who sell out our pensions seeking compromise with the uncompromising power of money.

We need someone who will take that on. We may lose, but right now we are losing without even trying to win.

The message that would send to the NCAA would be loud and clear.  Harbaugh would never be allowed to coach again and the players would likely be suspended for at least a year.  You'd think a Mich alum would know at least a little bit about the rules of the game.

Lloyd Carr every year he was head coach made donations quite publicly to the Michigan women's teams.  What Lynch is implying is funding scholarships by giving money to the school.  What you've inferred is giving money directly to the students.

As a Michigan alum I am happy that they have a football coach that can deliver.

That said ...

I think that we will hopefully soon be at a "Pope Francis" moment in college sports where a very well paid coach will think about "giving" back some his his very high compensation to the students in the form of scholarships.

Think about what a message that would send.

Happy New Year To All

I went to a liberal arts college with an undistinguished Division III football program. I could not persuade the college President or Board that it made no sense to admit some of the best students in the world and then let them smash their heads together.  Good luck trying to get Notre Dame to give up football.

HELLO! SAD to say, a bodybuilder's pride is his PECS, not a weightlifter's!
Otherwise, this has BEN an above PARR, ORR upper TIER offering, INDIES extremely RETRYing times, from the mind of David Woolf!

He's the MIRA image of his DAD, Peter De Woolf...

IVE Gotta go, need to do an ARRAN!

You make a good point about expectations that I wanted to make if I had had more room. Inflation happens when people in a position to set prices decide to raise them. Period. It's 100% human behavior based on expectations and (sometimes faulty) data. EXPECTING costs to rise -- a wage/price spiral-- is one example of mass behavior causing inflation. (and it has nothing to do with the money supply). Devaluing currency in a public way will also produce inflation. Many people confuse increasing the supply of money with decreasing its value. They are not the same thing at all. Since money is basically a medium of exchange, more money means the possibility of more "exchanges." Merchants respond by seeking more sales, NOT raising prices.
Sorry to say but the St. Louis folks were wrong about the cause & effect. Even Friedman stated that when increased money translates into increased output, there is no inflation.

Rima Regas:

Police departments around the country have gotten too big for their britches.

****
It's understandable that police officers would resent this mentality. Can't say I blame them.

That's not to say that I don't believe they need better rules of engagement, but we cannot lose sight of the fact that they still have to a tough and dangerous job to do, while everyone is marching around them accusing them of being killers, racists and criminals.

To seek to punish them, to knock them down a notch, is unproductive. We need them functioning, not hunkering down, reacting and feeling under attack.
We've already tried Obama moving right and compromising, or trying to compromise with those who take it all. That didn't work.

Why, thank you, Martin, may both you and Elaine have the same!

Howie and Librarose

Hahaha, your funny. Your taking the word of Sony's "incapable" IT? The same "incapable" IT that let it happen? If they are so incapable, as many of these posts basically say, how is it then they are just capable enough to determine it wasn't North Korea? Stop drawing conclusions and bending the truth. Instead, focus on the matter at heart, THE CRIME THAT WAS COMMITTED! A man walks into a crowded business and shoots everyone. You think you should fire the manager cause he didn't have security guards with guns to stop the man? GET REAL!
Sony executives and theatrical chains showed themselves to be the narrow-sighted tools we all knew they were. Perhaps they need advanced lessons in GTD.

"The federal government does far less to ameliorate the disparities than the governments of other developed countries."

Those words are written about tax transfers, but they apply generally.

Our country is this way because our government quite deliberately makes it this way. Government by the 1% and for the 1%, and only them.

what evidence can you cite that "North Korea involvement looks increasingly unlikely"?

Kim's regime was pretty adamant that the release of this movie was an "act of war". Would his regime hacking be a surprise?
don't worry, only low level peons in IT will lose their jobs.
Yes, Kim should be permitted to dictate what movies can and cannot be made in much the same manner that Khomeini wanted to dictate that the Satanic Versus (a mediocre book) not be made.

So not only was Sony remarkably unprepared for a cyber attack, but their impressively unsophisticated series of responses (technical, legal, etc.) sought to blame absolutely everyone except for one guilty party - Sony themselves. Talk about a naked emperor!
